document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Australian bee fly genus Meomyia Evenhuis, 1983, with description of three new species (Bombyliidae, Bombyliinae, Bombyliini)

(36). Type-locality: “Nouvelle-Hollande” [= Australia ]; Holotype , NHMUK.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Meomyia albiceps ( Macquart, 1848 )
. Holotype of
Bombylius albiceps Macquart, 1848
(NHMUK 010921897). (a) dorsal; (b) lateral. Scale bars = 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Posterior margin of scutum without black band. Male fore tibiae with black hair tuft on apical half. Anterior margin of male epandrium slightly concave. Apex of epiphallus of male gonocoxite bifid, with wide branch.
Redescription. Male. Body length 8.9–13.1 mm , wing length 8.1–11.2 mm .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Meomyia albiceps ( Macquart, 1848 )
. External (a–i (♂); j–o (♀)): (a, j) dorsal; (b, k) lateral; (c) antenna, lateral; (d) wing; (e) fore tibia, posterior; (f, l) head, dorsal; (g, m) head, frontal; (h, n) head, profile; (i, o) head, lateral. Scale bars = 1 mm (a, b, d–o); = 0.1 mm (c).

FIGURE 3.
Meomyia albiceps ( Macquart, 1848 )
. Genitalia (a–e (♂); f, g (♀)): (a) genital capsule, dorsal; (b) genital capsule, ventral; (c) genital capsule, lateral; (d) epandrium, dorsal; (e) epandrium, lateral; (f) sternite 8, ventral; (g) genitalia and spermathecae. Scale bars = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Thorax . Integumental colour of scutum mostly black with sparse grey pruinescence. Scutum covered with white hairs, hairs denser on anterior half, posterior margin admixed with black hairs, postalar callus with six brownish yellow setae and admixed with black hairs. Nine brownish yellow notopleural setae present. Scutellum black with sparse grey pruinescence, pruinescence denser on the margin, covered with black hairs, posterior margin admixed with brownish yellow hairs and setae. Pleura black with thick pale pruinescence, mostly covered in long white hairs, except anterodorsal area of anepisternum with yellow setae, anepimeron, meron, laterotergite and mediotergite bare.

Legs . Legs mostly brown except fore and mid tibia yellow; femora mostly covered in white scales and hairs, except covered in black scales on apical area; fore and mid tibia covered in white scales, except outer face admixed with black scales, and apical area covered in black scales, hind tibiae covered in black scales. Fore femur with one anterior bristle; mid femur with one row of anterior bristles; hind femur with one row of anteroventral bristles, and more separate bristles on apical half. Fore tibiae with outer tuft on apical half, nearly as wide as fore tibiae, consisting of dense long black hairs ( Fig. 2e ); mid tibiae sometimes with unconspicuous outer tuft on apical half, much narrower than mid tibiae. Bristles and other hairs on legs brown. Fore tibia 2.3 x longer than fore basitarsus, mid tibia 2.7 x longer than mid basitarsus, hind tibia 2.2 x longer than hind basitarsus.

Wings . Wing membrane hyaline. Cell
r 5
closed; cell br shorter than cell bm , crossvein r-m arising from base of cell dm ; crossvein m-m 0.7 x as long as crossvein r-m ; cell cua open ( Fig. 2d ). Haltere stem and knob blackish brown.

Abdomen . Integumental colour of tergites black mostly with thick grey pruinescence. Tergite 1 with dense white hairs; tergite 2 with dense black hairs; tergites 3–4 with dense white hairs; tergites 5–7 with dense black hairs, except median bare; tergite 8 with dense white hairs. Sternites black with thick pale pruinescence, sternites 1–4 covered in dense white hairs, sternites 5–7 covered in dense black hairs. Genitalia . Epandrium anterior and posterior margins slightly concave ( Fig. 3d ). Lateral margin of gonocoxite nearly straight ( Figs 3 a–b); apex of epiphallus bifid, branch wide and acute apically ( Fig. 3c ).

Remarks. Roberts (1928: 417) considered
Bombylius vetustus
and
Bombylius penicillatus
as synonyms of
Bombylius albiceps
. However, this synonymy was not followed by Evenhuis & Greathead (1999) . Based on our examination of the types , we confirm all three species are valid (see ‘7.
Meomyia penicillata ( Macquart, 1850 )
’ and ‘9.
Meomyia vetusta (Macquart, 1849)
’ later).
